subject: RE: [junit] Documenting test cases
msgSnippet: What about the documentation?  If I declare more specific exceptions, a la public void testAFile() throws FileNotFoundException { ... } then I can document why

What about the documentation?  If I declare more specific exceptions, a la 
 
    public void testAFile() throws FileNotFoundException {
        ...
  }
 
then I can document why it might fail:
    @throws FileNotFoundException when the test file "foo" is not found, but
it should always be found. This might indicate a problem with ...
 
And to your other post, I agree, never write an empty test.  Either it has
real test code, it fails("not written"), or it doesn't exist. 
 
 
Thanks
--DP

-----Original Message-----
From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...] 
Sent: Wednesday, July 14, 2004 4:05 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Documenting test cases


David Plass wrote:

> When writing test cases my fingers automatically type:
> 
>     public void testTheMethodBeingTested() throws Exception {
>     }
> 
> Is it acceptable to write "throws Exception"?  Or should I
>     1. Only declare thrown exceptions I expect
>     2. Not declare anything thrown
>     3. Other

I always throw Exception from tests, because I /know/ (one of the rare 
times I know something) that I want to let JUnit catch any unexpected 
exceptions. Since my Eclipse code template types it for me, there is no 
extra work in adding the code and there is no maintenance cost. As a 
result, it is pure profit, so I always do it.
--
